subject: Re: New Zealand dialect
msgSnippet: ... are ... Yes indeed. Actually I, like you, do *not* believe there is any difficulty communicating between accents and that variations in spelling are
messageBody:
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "C. Paige Gabhart"
<pgabhart@...> wrote:
>
> Tony:
>
> I appreciate all the time that has been spent in developing the use of
> these lexical sets. I will say that to some extent I see this as an
> attempt by group members who are quite new to QS to work out what they
> see as a problem. I believe Moira commented that different accents
are
> not as much of a problem as you seem to believe and her assertion is
> proven by the letter writing campaign in QS that went on 30 years or
> more ago. For example, I have letters written in 1975 by a New
> Zealander. I can't remember having any trouble reading his QS.
>
> If Paul pronounces bear and beer the same, it just means his QS will
> have two homonyms that most people's dialect doesn't. Surely, the
> difference will come out in context. "I love a cold bear after cutting
> the grass" is hardly open to much confusion although it might cause a
> smile among those of us who don't merge those two sounds.
>
> Paige
>

Yes indeed. Actually I, like you, do *not* believe there is any
difficulty communicating between accents and that variations in
spelling are irrelevant; that a phonemic treatment of QS is
serviceable. But I was not quite believed when I said so. Nor were my
little attempts at proof.

And thank goodness they were not believed: phonemic QS may be
serviceable but lexical set QS may work even better.

The current exercise may have started with "how do you spell 'air'"
but has now become an opportunity to allow very modern linguistic
techniques to be brought to the Read Alphabet. And if the participants
are new to QS, I think their knowledge of linguistics is world class.
What might be being built by the participants as a mere hobby and
break from work could be on par with a real work of academia. I'm more
than happy to aid in anyway my humble skills and finite time allow.
